My thoughts...

- JUnit must be stable.  My development team depends on JUnit.  I'd 
rather have fewer new features that are well designed and developed 
than many features that are poorly designed and implemented.

- If you are going to transfer control to the community, why 
not "Community Planning Game".  That is, implement the XP Planning 
Game where the community is the customer.  The community could 
express what they desire (stories) and set priorities.

- Providing hooks for extensions would be great.  Right now, the most 
frequently use hook is subclassing.  Unfortunately this makes it 
difficult to use two extensions at once.

- Greg


--- In junit@y..., "Johannes Link" <john.link@g...> wrote:
> > 2. JUnit as a political gesture celebrates the ability of 
programmers
> > to test their own software. The code and tests must be held to a
> > higher standard, to demonstrate the techniques necessary to uphold
> > our end of the bargain.
> 
> I'd like to add two aspects:
> - JUnit should be the stable angle for the very unstable projects 
we all
> have to do. Changing too much jeopardizes stableness.
> - When adding too much non-core functionality one quickly looses 
focus of
> the core parts. Very often the extra functionality is not exactly 
what I
> need in a specific situation, so I have to reimplement it anyway. 
If the
> unneeded and unwanted part of a tool is prevailing many will move 
towards
> starting from scratch with a new (small) framework. That's why I'd 
rather
> have JUnit as a core with hooks to plug in additional behaviour 
which is
> available in additional tools.
> 
> BTW, is the move to version 4 as described in
> http://c2.com/cgi/wiki?JunitNextRelease
> an "official" thing, i.e. promoted by Kent and Erich?
> 
> Johannes
